G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, residential tenants are protected by an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified at G.L. c. 186, § 14, which provides that a landlord shall not, directly or indirectly, interfere with the quiet enjoyment of the premises by the tenant.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.raw_text: *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 applies regardless of whether it is expressly stated in the written lease, and is deemed a part of all residential tenancies in Massachusetts.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a separate concurring/dissenting opinion and focuses on implied warranty of habitability and code-based implied covenants. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, or state that a statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment is part of all residential tenancies regardless of lease language. Without the majority opinion text on § 14, this passage cannot be used as authority for the claimed proposition.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: "If it were now necessary or appropriate to indicate by dictum what the ultimate scope of our new rule might be, beyond the necessities of the present cases, I would state it to be (a) that by renting a dwelling unit a landlord impliedly agrees, with respect to the minimum standards prescribed by any applicable laws, regulations or codes (such as the State Sanitary Code) having the force and effect of law, (i) that the rented unit complies with such standards at the time of the renting, and (ii) that he will do whatever such laws, regulations or codes require a landlord to do for compliance with such standards during the term of the renting..."}

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 629 N.E.2d 301 (1994);
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Substantial interferences with the tenant’s ability to use and enjoy the premises, including chronic or serious conditions affecting safety, security, or habitability, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that if drug-related activity in the common areas renders sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreational areas unusable and prevents tenants from safely and peacefully living in their homes, this can be a “serious interference” that substantially impairs the character of the leasehold and thus breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion squarely links chronic, serious safety and security problems affecting tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises to a potential breach of the statutory covenant, contingent on factual proof at trial.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Medeiros v. Hous. Auth. of Fall River*,.proposition: Substantial interferences with the tenant’s ability to use and enjoy the premises, including chronic or serious conditions affecting safety, security, or habitability, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Medeiros v. Hous. Auth. of Fall River*,.case_name: Salem Country Club, Inc. v. Peabody Redevelopment Authority
*Medeiros v. Hous. Auth. of Fall River*,.support_reasoning: The opinion is an eminent domain valuation case involving Salem Country Club and has nothing to do with landlord-tenant law, residential leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It addresses how anticipated improvements and development potential affect fair market value in a taking, not interferences with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Medeiros v. Hous. Auth. of Fall River*,.relevant_excerpt: "In assessing eminent domain damages sustained by Salem Country Club, Inc. (Salem), from the loss through a taking of about forty-two and a half acres, the trial judge, sitting without a jury, heard and considered evidence concerning the likelihood of public action and private land acquisition which would improve access to the land taken. ... We affirm the judgment, insofar as it fixed the fair market value of the premises taken at $957,150."

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..proposition: A landlord may be liable for a breach when the interference with quiet enjoyment results from the landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to correct conditions in the common areas of the building that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses landlord liability for interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 based on failure to remedy conditions causing repeated flooding. It emphasizes that the landlord had a duty to maintain sanitary, watertight premises, that flooding from a common-area source was a “preventable situation,” and that liability attached because the landlord, after notice, did not take appropriate steps to correct a condition that substantially interfered with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the apartment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question ... that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 35.proposition: A landlord may be liable for a breach when the interference with quiet enjoyment results from the landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to correct conditions in the common areas of the building that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 35.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on conditions (here, excessive noise) created by another tenant where the landlord, after complaints, had the right and ability to control or correct those conditions but failed to do so. The court explicitly rejects a strict malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction and emphasizes that landlord liability may arise from what the landlord failed to do or permitted to be done when it substantially interferes with habitability. This squarely supports liability for failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to correct common-area–type interferences that substantially affect use and enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 35.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 430 N.E.2d 869 (1982).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 does not require proof of malice or bad faith; it is enough that the landlord, after notice, failed to act reasonably to prevent or correct conditions that foreseeably and substantially interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment does not depend on the landlord’s intent or financial ability, but on the foreseeable consequences of the landlord’s conduct. The court states that intent is not required and that liability is imposed whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s actions is an interruption of the tenant’s rights, effectively adopting an objective reasonableness/foreseeability standard rather than a malice or bad-faith requirement.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to… an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”
